title: Why Does My Car Stall When I Come to a Stop?

steps.title: Check the dipstick on the automatic transmission.
steps.content: Check the dipstick on the automatic transmission . [1] X Research source Check the owner's manual for the correct procedure for your vehicle — generally, manufacturers prefer testing with a warm engine. [2] X Research source Be sure to check the fluid when parked on a level surface. Do your best to not allow any lint or dirt to contaminate the dip stick before reinserting.

steps.title: Look for stalling, no power when accelerating.
steps.content: Look for stalling, no power when accelerating. The check engine light will likely be on. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Look under the car at night after the vehicle has been running for a while.
steps.content: Look under the car at night after the vehicle has been running for a while. If the catalytic converter is glowing, it's probably clogged. You will have to replace the converter if you find this to be the problem. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Look for initial idle OK after a cold engine start-up, but a warm engine idle will surge and stall.
steps.content: Look for initial idle OK after a cold engine start-up, but a warm engine idle will surge and stall.

steps.title: Take your car in to get a reading.
steps.content: Take your car in to get a reading. [5] X Research source After a few thousand miles of this, most cars will turn on the "check engine" light. You can take it to any AutoZone, Advance auto parts, Napa, or O'Reilly's (but some places may only check cars made after 1996, so call and check first) and they will read the codes for free. There can be any number of reasons for the "check engine" light to come on, so it is good to check. Codes complaining of unexpected lean mixture is a good indication of O2 sensor failure. O2 sensors will typically last 60–75K miles. The good news is that you can buy an O2 sensor online for around $50 and they are generally pretty easy to replace. [6] X Research source Another possible reason is that the engine is idling too low (the idle is adjustable) or the control module is going out, which is relatively inexpensive and easy to access and fix.

steps.title: Look for the Engine Code Error (EGE) P1406.
steps.content: Look for the Engine Code Error (EGE) P1406. If the EGR valve is stuck open , the car will run sluggish at lower RPMs. If the valve is stuck closed, the car won't run well at higher RPMs (on the highway).

steps.title: Try cleaning the excess carbon out of the EGR valve first.
steps.content: Try cleaning the excess carbon out of the EGR valve first. It may just need to be cleaned and not need replacing. [7] X Research source If cleaning the EGR valve does not work and you are still getting code P1406, the EGR valve needs to be replaced. [8] X Research source
